I understand you're trying to make an important point about probability density functions, but I wish you hadn't titled this "Why “probability of 0” does not mean “impossible”". When we speak of discrete (finite) probability distributions, "probability zero" does in fact mean impossible. This is extremely important when speaking of "true" and "false". It's epistemologically crucial to be clear that one is never justified in assigning any non-analytic proposition a probability of zero or one. I could say that's the main difference between religion and science. I've had long, fruitless arguments with rationalists, trying to explain why there is no such thing as "true" or "false" in empirical science, or why I can't allow code to assign a probability of zero to a particular outcome just because we haven't observed it once in a billion cases. For example, when using Markov models to detect genes in genomes, there will be so many DNA sequences that aren't in your training set, that you'll inevitably run into some of them in your real-life data--and your program will simply fail to detect those new genes.

TL;DR: In discrete distributions, a probability of zero means impossible.

The word "is" and "of" is generally considered to mean "equal to" in these contexts, so saying "a probability of 0" is interpreted as "a probability equal to 0". Now that means completely impossible.

However what you mean, is "a probability approaching to 0", and then everything is valid.

If the probability of each one is EXACTLY equal to 0, then the sum is always 0 no matter what, but if they are just approaching to 0, the sum can be anything.

So the statement in english "probability of 0 does not mean impossible" is wrong in the correct interpretation of the words.

Your logic in the video also shows you clearly mean "approaching to 0", as you show your visuals and wording exactly in that way.

I don't get the "throwing a dart at a dartboard" example. How could the probability of hitting a particular point be 0? Wouldn't the probability of a random throw hitting a particular point on the board be the area of the dart tip divided by the area of the dartboard?

Let's assume we're using the area of the entire dartboard, not just the playable area. That's 17.75" in diameter, for a total area of about 247.45 square inches. A modern standard dart tip has a diameter of 3.45mm, which is an area of about 0.145 square inches. 247.5/0.145 is about 1707, so the probability of a dart hitting a random point on the board is about 1/1707 or 0.00058. Small, but much more than zero.

This is for a steel tip dartboard.

Any one particular point on the dartboard may be infinitely small, or have no size, but the dartboard and the dart both have a definite size that can be measured and calculated, which would tell us the probability of the random point being within the area covered by the dart tip.

I think the probability of p(0.7) being 0 is just misleading.
When you demonstrate the bar distribution, it is clear that the probability (in a uniform distribution example) would be 1 / x, where x is the number of divisions. As x gets bigger, the probability gets smaller. One is tempted to quickly say that as x becomes infinity, the probability becomes 0, BUT that's where the intuition problem begins.

In reality, since as x gets bigger, the probability gets smaller, that means that no matter how big x is, the probability will never be 0. This is obvious since if your 0 means 'nothing' then by increasing x you would obtain a probability smaller than nothing which is not possible. In other words, 0 is not "nothing" in this context, but rather, an infinitely small number (to match x, an infinitely big one).

Once you have that realization, you can tell that the sum of the individual probabilities is not 0 * inf, but simply (1/inf)*inf. Usually this type of operation has no defined answer, but since we know our "0" came from that very same number of divisions, it is clear the answer is 1

Yes, “probability of 0” does mean “impossible”. Because consider what happens when you try to determine which probability-0 point you have hit: you cannot actually do so in a finite time. All you can do is narrow it down to an interval with a nonzero total probability, which gets smaller and smaller the more time and effort you spend computing it (convergence). So the exact probability-0 event that was hit requires an infinite amount of time and effort to narrow down. Which means you can’t do it.

When the video says 70%, it assumes that it is exactly 70.000000000 repeating to infinity precision, but that's not how humans talk about these things. When we say exactly, we mean it is that for all the digits we care about. Take height for example. If I were to say I was exactly 180 cm tall, you would assume that I mean I fall within a bin of 179.5-180.49 repeating cm, because we cannot measure infinitely precisely, partially because we lack the means to do so, but also because it makes no difference. Case in point, you say exactly 0.7, but you give it to 8 decimal places, but to be more precise, that is actually a bin itself from 0.699999999999 repeating to 0.700000004999999 repeating.

I think the title of this video is a bit of a cheat. Consider a random variable 0 <= x <= 1, and assume a uniform probability density. Ok, practically speaking, you are not going to be able to pick a sample from it that equals any pre-specified value. You can try as many times as you want, but you just won't produce it. If I look closely enough at your sample, it will be off by some amount. I see what you're saying in the title - we can't say that the specific value is impossible. But on the other hand you can't put together a real situation in which you can reliably produce it. This is really just getting into a situation where infinities aggravate things - you can't even create an experiment that lets you accurately conduct this study since you can't have an infinite number of possibilities to pull from. Any real situation will just have N large, and therefore the probability of selecting a PRECISE value is either 1/N, if that value happens to be one of the ones you put in the sample pool, or 0, if it doesn't. And if it's 0 in that sense, then it's IMPOSSIBLE for you to pick it, because it's not in there. See what I'm saying? This is more an issue about infinities in math than it is anything about probability.

Now, all that said, it's a great video!

I actually first learned about this notion by coming at it from computer science, and the application in question is fascinating. One very important result in the field is “FLP impossibility,” named after the authors of the paper, which states that if you have several computers on a network that are trying to agree on a single value, and it’s possible both that one of those computers can crash and that messages sent between computers on that network can be delayed a finite but unbounded number of time steps, then there is simply no algorithm that can possibly guarantee that all the non-crashed computers come to agree on the same value, or achieve consensus, which is the term of art. But! It turns out that there are algorithms that guarantee that, even with that same network and possibility of a computer crashing, the remaining computers failing to agree on a value is an outcome that happens with probability zero in the sense discussed here. I think it's better to think of it as "an infinitely small number does not necessarily equal precisely 0."
It would make more sense to say that the probability of a point is not 0, but rather infinitely small.

The dimensionality MUST match. You cannot place an exact number on a continuous line without getting nonsense. How many points are required to make up a line segment? The point is 0-dimensional, unit-less element. The line is a 1-dimensional element with unit length. Since the unis do not match, the point cannot be meaningfully scaled by any factor to match the line. There is no scalar quantity that will turn a 0-dimensional element into a 1-dimensional element. Talking about the probability of an exact number occurring on a continuous probability curve doesn't make any sense. You end up dealing with infinities (infinite samples, infinite time, infinite distances) and infinities can be used to prove all sorts of nonsense. If you end up with infinities, chances are you did something wrong. Instead of an exact value you have to use a range. P(h = 0.70000001) > 0 is meaningless. Instead it should be P(h = 0.70000001±0.00000005) > 0.

As an alternative example, consider the definition of integration. It is the sum between limits of a function multiplied by an infinitesimally small delta x. g(x) = Σf(x) Δx, which at the limit Δx -> dx, gives the standard integration form. But, the limit does not mean that dx=0. Δx tends to 0. It does not equate to 0. In the same way, the probability should be P(h = 0.70000001±Δh) > 0. Typically this may be shortened to P(h = 0.70000001) > 0, BUT the range is still implied. And the range never equates to 0, it just tends to 0.

So, a probability of 0 does mean impossible.

I think this whole concept is a lot easier understood if we think of it in terms of precision or tolerance. E.g. what is the probability that I am exactly 1.8 m tall? Well, we need to remember, that, in mathematical terms, that 'exactly' means that the measurement is 1.800000... with an infinite number of zeroes behind it. In reality, if the measurement is 1.8 m, it is extremely likely - in fact, certain - that somewhere in those decimals there will be a deviation (e.g. it is really 1.8000346...)

When someone measures my height, there is always the issue of measurement precision. E.g. if the precision is ±1 mm, when they measure me as 1.8 m, what it really means is that it is somewhere between 1.799 and 1.801 - i.e. a range of real numbers. While the probability of being exactly 1.8 m is zero, the probability of being in that range (which we loosely call 1.8 m) is higher than zero.

The probability of a 0.6, is not the probability of 0.600000... with infinitely many zeros, but the probability of 0.6 and all numbers that round to 0.6. Its probability width is 0.1, similarly the probability width of 0.35 would then be 0.01. This also means that if you add up all probabilities for all numbers it would only equal infinity if you included all possible decimals to infinite decimal places. The reason for my confusion is this that is true for literally any function where you're trying to find an integral (and not only probability functions). If you're taking the integral where the starting point is the same as the end point, then you're always going to end up at 0.
I'm not well educated enough in Mathematics to say definitively that this concept breaks down in such a context, however, I don't really see why its much of a problem that if you were to take an infinite number of integrals--all of which are zero--and they don't add up to one. After all, other functions clearly have an area under the curve (even if we can't say exactly what that area is), and they have exactly the same sort of "paradox."
Isn't it enough to just understand that we're not literally talking about a "bar" that literally has no width, and instead has an arbitrarily small width? I feel like this is forgetting about what we're doing when we actually define a limit. We're not actually taking the width to zero, but instead we're taking what the width is as it approaches zero, and therefore there's not really even a point in thinking about what the area is when talking about a single point on the x axis.

I don't know measure theory, and I'm probably missing out, but I just don't understand why you have to go into something like that to think about this, and instead shouldn't we just be talking about the formal definition of a limit?

I might be wrong, I am not mathematician, but I think the claim "probability of 0 doesn't mean impossible" isn't really true. As I remember, the probability of 0 means always impossible in discrete probability, because the probability of the event is defined as number favorable outcomes divided by the number of all possible outcomes. So the only way to get zero is when there is 0 favorable outcomes, which mean that those outcomes aren't in the set of all possible outcomes and therefore it cannot occur. And if it occurs, then it must be in the set of all possible outcomes and therefore has non zero probability. In the case of continuous probability, I think that there just cases when it doesn't make sense to ask what the probability of the event is. For example, imagine that we are generating random numbers inside a unit circle centered in (0, 0), then the probability of generating certain number in a certain region is (if consider that distribution is uniform) the area of the region divided by total area of circle (considering that the region is fully contained inside the circle). But when you are working with regions that doesn't have area, than the probability will always be zero, because the integral over that region would always be zero (if I am not wrong). So the only meaningful way of talking about probabilities in this context is to consider region that has area. If you consider what is probability of generating number inside a square defined by 2 <= x <= 3, 0 <= y <= 1, than the probability would be zero and it does mean that it is impossible to generate number that are inside that square, because, well, we are generating numbers inside a circle and clearly the square doesn't intersect with the circle. But if we could generate number that would be inside that square, that it must mean that the probability isn't zero. And this reasoning should apply for every region that has non zero area. Basically what I want to say is that, as I think, if we consider regions that have areas, than the probability of 0 would always mean that the event is impossible. But it's just what I could conclude whit my poor knowledge of probabilities, so I might be wrong.

Note: while I was writing that comment, I realized that that last part might not be true. If we generate some discrete points (or, maybe, infinitely many that doesn't form a region with area) in the square, then the probability of generating number inside the square might be zero while it is still possible to generate number that is inside the square. But in that case we won't be able to calculate the probability of generating the number inside a square by dividing its area with the area of the whole domain (because that set of points doesn't have area). So I think that in that case we are running into the same problem and it doesn't make sense to ask what is the probability, but I am not sure.

The thing is that the probabilities you are speaking of aren't zero, but just infinitesimally small. They might be infinitely tiny but still above zero.
Something that is impossible, has really a probability of zero and is really impossible. So it doesn't even make sense to make a distribution for it. If a probability is truly zero, then there is only one single outcome, no matter what you try.
The other extreme of having something that is guaranteed to happen with an individual prbability of 100% also makes no sense to make a distribution of, because there is only one outcome.
Also, just because something is mathematically possible, doesn't mean that it is really possible in our physical world. The main problem with statistics, in practice with our limited datasets, is that we only assume the probablities by making assumptions without knowing the real probabilities. "Namely, if the probabilities for each value in a given range (of the real number line) are all non-zero, no matter how small, their sum will be infinite." said in the description text. To counter that statement, there are many ways to add up an infinite series of numbers and end up with a finite sum (0.9 + 0.09 + 0.009 + ... comes to mind). Also, if you add up a constant an infinite number of times, you have to use an infinitesimal to end up with a finite sum, all other constant number times infinity is equal to infinity. "Probability of zero" also include infinitesimal probability; this is an extension of the traditional probability theory for cases where infinity plays an important role. You can for example have an infinite lottery or, like in the example here, an infinite number of possible geometrical points to hit. Together, the infinite number of infinitesimals will add up to 100%, just like all probabilities in standard (real number) probability theory.

I think it may be easier for people to understand if they consider what it even means to specify the number of interest. This comes down to significant figures. When one says 70% probability, what really is meant is 70% +/- 0.5%, or 70.0 +/- 0.05%, or 70.00 +/- 0.005%. At some point there is a limited degree of precision expected, because they probably aren't asking for the difference in likelihood of the probability being 70.0000000000% versus 70.0000000001%. Thus when it is asked what the probability of the probability being 70% is, what is really being asked is what the probability of the probability being within some expected tolerance of 70%, which ties directly into the concept of integrating over a probability density function.

A lot of the apparent disconnect between discrete and continuous distributions disappears (or, at least, shrinks) when you approach things from the perspective of non-standard analysis.  If f is the PDF for a continuous random variable, X, then the probability that X equals some value x is not zero but f(x) * dx, which is some infinitesimal non-standard real number.  That's why \sum P(X=x) in the discrete case turns into \integral f(x) dx in the continuous case.

Of course probability 0 doesn't mean impossible. Probability 0 events are constantly happening, an infinite number of them. For instance, the odds that a randomly chosen moment in the day is between 1 and 2 pm is 1 in 24. The odds that a randomly chosen moment is between 1:00 and 1:01 pm is 1 in 1440. The odds that it's 1 pm EXACTLY? Is 0. And yet it happens every day. And every other specific time has probability 0 and happens every day too. There is a continuum of probability 0 events that constantly happen every moment of every day.

It's actually quite similar to integration (the second key propertie of the pdf is in fact the integration over the entire domain equals to 1). We start working with the limit of an average interval for instance, with the width of the interval tending to zero but with a specific area. The area actually does go away in the limit, but as we're working with limits we never define the function "in" the limit, so there's always an area that we sum up, and in the limit they all add up to 1.

I actually did that 2 years back.
Let's say you have 6 plausible mechanism and no tests yet. Since we have no tests, the probability of every mechanism is equal and the sum of the product of the mechanism result and mechanism probability will be as follows: 0%/6+20%/6+40%/6+ ... =50%.
if you have 1 positive test. Now every mechanism will have a different likelihood, namely the square of its positive rate, divided by the sum of these squares (hence all probabilities should add up to one).

if instead of quantizing our mechanisms by 6, we can do infinity. Which would mean that instead of a Riemann Summ we use an Integral. Funnily enough the x to any power will always be 1 (since our integral ends at 1), so the only important thing in these integrals will be the resulting divisor. If you play things through a few times you'll see a very elegant property that the empirical probability equals (1+p)/(2+t) where p are the positive results and t are the total trials.

One of the best analogies I've gotten about "probability 0" and "probability 1" is from the mathematician David Kelly. He explained it like this: When you break a stick at a random location, with probability 1 something with probability 0 happens. You will break the stick somewhere - but the probability of getting breaking at the point you did is still zero.
Something with probability 0 doesn't mean it can't happen, and probability 1 doesn't mean it will.

Puzzle : "if the probabilities for each value in a given range (of the real number line) are all non-zero, no matter how small, their sum will be infinite"

Let X be an uncountable set and f a function from X to ]0, +oo[

Lets prove that ∑ f(x) (for x in X) = +oo :

For each x in X, f(x) > 0 so there exists n in N* such that f(x) > 1/n
Let E_n = {x in X | f(x) > 1/n}
X = Union E_n (for n in N*)
If each E_n is finite then X is a countable union of finite sets and thefore X is countable. That is false (by hypothesis) so there is a m in N* such that E_m is infinite
∑ f(x) (for x in X) >= ∑f(x) (for x in E_m) >= ∑1/m (for x in E_m) = +oo * 1/m = +oo

When I think about "probability 0" vs "impossible", the following example comes to mind. Suppose you have a uniform distribution on [0,1]. The probability that you will get 1/2 is exactly the same as the probability of getting 2. There is no mathematically sensible way of treating these two events as different, because you can take this probability measure on the real line, swap 1/2 and 2 (that is, compose with a bijection that swaps 1/2 and 2 and leaves every other point in place), and you will get exactly the same probability measure. (Continuous) probability measures simply don't care about the values of points.

This has an even more disturbing consequence, though. If you pick a value from the distribution, that point will have probability 0, so you have to conclude that points with probability 0 are possible. But then you have to also conclude that points like 2 are possible from the distribution [0,1], as well as other implausible values like i and donald trump. I don't know the resolution to this, unless you reject the idea that the "picking" can happen in the first place. It sort of calls into question what probability is purporting to describe in the first place.

I'm not sure I agree with the route you take here (I'm almost sure I disagree). My intro to probability went with defining cumulative probability functions, which are more robust and cover both discrete and continuous cases. From the CPFs you can get to PDFs noting the conditions for a PDF to work (i.e. that the distribution is absolutely continuous). And you can get to the meat of "what is a σ-algebra necessary for?" in a fairly intuitive way. The CDF defines probabilities for semi-open intervals in the form  ]-inf,x] and the generated σ-algebra for these intervals is the Borell-Algebra, which then allows you to use the normal rules for probability (probability of complement and σ-additivity) to get a probability for any set in B from the CDF.

Since probabilities are all positive you get an absolutely convergent series. That means that no matter how you rearrange numbers the sum will still be the same.
But there is no well-defined way to add uncountably many numbers, so you just don't do that.

To me it makes sense that the dart has a probability of 0 of hitting a specific point on the dart board. If you are aiming at a specific point, it means that you are betting on the fact that your accuracy will be on the level of atoms, and even smaller (because math has no Planck length). You literally are boasting infinite accuracy, which is impossible. That is why your probability of hitting that specific point is 0. But if you say "I am going to hit Bullseye". Then things change, now you are being reasonable. The bet is no longer on hitting the infinitely small point, but rather hitting an area which contains infinitely many of these infinitely small points. In some sense you have infinitely higher probability now since you have infinitely many small points. But of course in our real world we have the Planck length which means that we are never really talking about infinity, just very big or very small numbers. That also means that the probability is never truly 0, however it is extremely tiny. ^^

Manipulating continuous probability laws

Integrals : let us introduce ourselves

I always thought, in the continuous case, having probability of 0 for any specific number really meant having a 0 probability. If you flip a fair coin infinitely many times, probability of getting all Hs, or H, T, H, T, ... is actually zero. Similarly, probability of getting the number 0.25, from a uniform random distribution over [0, 1] is really zero. Since that number is actually 0.250000000... Which means the random number generator must generate a perfect, infinite sequence of zeros.
This also make sense when you consider the fact that rational numbers are countably infinite and they do not "take up any space" in the real number line. So, in a sense, probability of getting a specific rational, algebraic, computable, or any other countably infinite kind of number is really 0. This, of course does not solve any problems, but even so, I find the thought of getting a specific number that I can simply write down from a continuous probability distribution actually having zero probability intriguing.

The area of an infinitely/arbitrary small piece is not 0, it's just infinitely/arbitrarily small. In standard analysis, we don't usually try to assign any of those pieces specific values, instead we just take the limit as they go to 0. But it's still important to realize they're never actually 0. That's why the limit definition of the derivative makes sense. We can divide the h at the end without actually dividing by 0 and still drop it at the end because it isn't 0, but it is so small that adding it to a real number makes essentially no difference.
With regards to integration, which is how we rigorously define probability distributions, those pieces are also never 0. It's like if I start out with a whole, then I cut it in half, than I cut the half in half,l and then the quarter in half, and so on and so forth, ad infinitum. Each piece will smaller than the previous one and they'll just keep getting smaller and smaller, but we'll never get to one that actually has 0 size, though we will get arbitrarily close. All of those pieces will add up to 1, despite their small size -- they have to because we started with 1 at the beginning. If they all had 0 size, that couldn't happen. No matter how many 0's we add to together, we still get 0. But if the area is even slightly bigger than 0, eventually we'll get to 1, it'll just take a lot of pieces; infinitely many to be specific.

Nature somehow avoids the problems of zero dimension objects of infinitely small single points with zero volume / area. That's because in the physical world, the Planck length is the smallest possible dimension. Plus the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, physics forces you to ask about the probability of a range of values, rather than single points, at the quantum scale.

Gah, "probability" is never a physical thing, stop attributing it to real world events. It's a mathematical concept or model of reality constructed solely in your head, with values heavily determined by your prior assumptions (in mathematical mumbo jumbo, one could say all probabilities are conditional).

Substitute the word "frequency" for "probability" and all the mystery disappears - because it automatically raises the follow-up question "frequency of what among what". You can measure frequencies only after having answered that question. And you can assume that the next result will reflect that measured frequency. Unless of course something physical has changed in between your measurement and the result that makes it not so.

Also look up "mind projection fallacy", a term coined by E.T. Jaynes to describe people who start believing that their own made-up models are real.

7:35 : You can combine the discrete and continuous case without bringing measure theory or integrals into it by using cumulative distribution functions (CDFs). The way this works is, if F is the CDF for a real-valued random variable X, then F(a) is the probability that the true value of X is less than or equal to a. If X is a discrete random variable with probability mass function p, then F(a) is the sum of p(t) for t from −∞ to a, and if X is a continuous random variable with probability density function f, then F(x) is the integral of f(t)dt for t from −∞ to a (and if X is a random variable with Borel measure μ, then F(x) is the measure under μ of the closed interval from −∞ to a). But if you work with F all along, then you don't have to discuss measure, or integration, or even summation. You do have to talk about one-sided limits, but as this is a Calculus topic that comes well before even Riemann integration, that's not too bad.

Some example calculations: F(b) minus F(a) is the probability that the value of X is in the range from a to b, including b but excluding a. (This is true regardless of whether the distribution is discrete, continuous, or a mixture of these.) If you want the probability including both a and b, then you use the limit of F(b) minus F(t) as t approaches a from below. If instead you want the probability including neither a nor b, then you use the limit of F(t) minus F(a) as t approaches b from below. If you want the probability that the value is exactly a, then this is the limit of F(a) minus F(t) as t approaches a from below; this is zero if F is continuous at a but positive if F is discontinuous at a. (In general, where F is continuous, the probabilities are continuous; and where F is discontinuous or constant, the probabilities are discrete.)

Technicalities: A real-valued function F, defined on the entire real line, counts as a CDF of something if F is weakly increasing (aka non-decreasing), all one-sided limits exist, the right-hand limits equal the values of the function (so F is right-continuous), the limit approaching −∞ is 0, and the limit approaching ∞ is 1. (It's a theorem that such functions correspond one-to-one with Borel measures on the real line, as in my first paragraph.) So you can start probability theory working with this concept, and the only thing from Calculus that you need to define it is one-sided limits.

This is not to say that you can do all of probability theory without bringing in integrals or measures! If you want to define the expectation value, for example, using only a random variable's CDF, then you can't do this with just limits. (You have to use the Lebesgue–Stieltjes integral, in general.) So this is not a panacea. But it does nicely tie discrete and continuous probability together in one simple idea.

In layman's terms, we usually refer to the odds of something extremely specific happening, like a ball landing on a particular molecule marked on it's face as "infinitesimally small", with the assumption that there's some absurdly long string of zeros following the decimal point that's not worth counting. So because the ball has a limited number of molecules, even if we're trying to drop it on a specific spot on the floor at the same time, we'll eventually run out of possible outcomes. The infinite probability curve paradox is amusing on paper, but not very applicable to the real world. I like to borrow the fundamental concept of quantum mechanics and view continuous probability as an approximation, where the real distribution is quantized according to some unknown scheme. If the scheme of quantization is known, you can enumerate all possibilities and assign non-zero probabilities to them. But since the scheme of quantization is unknown or difficult to model, we cannot know which outcomes are possible, so we have infinitely-many possibilities to consider and thus cannot give them individual probabilities. However, the probability of an outcome being in a particular range can still be modeled.

Applies over the Reals (and thus over the rationals, etc). But it doesn't apply over the Surreal Numbers, or any other ordered field with infinitesimals like the Hyperreals. For example, {1, 2, 3, 4, ... |} * {0 | 1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, ...} = 1 (in any set theory which permits transfinite induction up to $S_{\omega^2}$).

Given the passing of Conway it might be nice to do a video on the Surreals. They're one of his lesser known but more interesting constructs, though the Hyperreals are a more popular way to get the same results (they're isomorphic to the Surreals if the Axiom of Global Choice is accepted). But I find the Surreals to have a far more intuitive construction than the Ultrapower Construction of the Hyperreals.

Edit: After finishing the video, of course model theory is brought up. That's very closely related to nonstandard analysis, which uses the hyperreal numbers.

2:05 the way i see it, the probability of any of those values is not 0. It’s an infinitesimal (1/inf). Something that exists but with an infinitely small value is not the same as it not existing at all.

For example the probability of the value being 0.70001 is (1/inf), but the probability of the value being 2.0 is 0, because it can never ever be that value.

So if there’s an infinite number of possible values from 0.0 to 1.0, each at (1/inf), then you get
(inf x 1/inf) = 1

This might be overly philosophical, but with regards to the dartboard example, there really isn't a bullseye in real physical space. As a geometric construction, it is a novelty: a possible event, with probability zero. How wacky! But really, if you zoom in enough, you have dart molecules piercing a surface of board molecules, and so there isn't really an infinitely divisible set of zero-dimensional points that the dart can hit. One corollary of this is that there is no real way to hit a bullseye, or maybe there are many, because it is not a question of infinite precision. Conversely, though, it is also true that if we define a bullseye as hitting an arbitrarily small area of the center of the dartboard, with a dart that has a tip of finite area, then it is not actually a probability=zero event.

6:05 Are you sure!? I think this not true in a countably infinite context.

Imagine you have countably infinite possibilities and exactly one of them obtains. Then the probability that the one which obtains is in the collection of possibilities is 1. Since we don't know which possibility obtains, we have to treat their probabilities as equal. But then it cannot be true that their sum is equal to the probability 1 that one of all the possibilities obtains. If a single possibility had probability greater than 0 then the sum would be greater than 1 (presumably infinite). And if the probability of a single possibility would be 0 them the sum would also be 0. If the sum would give the right result it would be 1. But it isn't 1 so the sum doesn't give the right result.

So the countably infinite case has the same problem as the continuous case: The probability that one of them obtains cannot be the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities. Because this would not yield the correct result "1". However, the solution with the integral for continuous cases doesn't seem to work for countably infinite cases! We need a different solution. But which one?

For the riddle, let a_i be a non negatieve sequence, where i runs over an uncountable index. Lets assume that the sum convergences. Then the set {a_i > 1/n} must be of finite size, since the sum is lowerbounded by 1/n times the size of that set. Taking the union over all n, and using the fact that the countable union of finite sets is countable, gives that the amount of positive entries in the sum is countable. Thus, any sum with uncountable positive term is infinite

To show sum of non-negative uncountable set is unbounded [ Here the set is F = { f(x) : x belongs to S } where S is the interval [0,1] ]
ASSUMPTION: An uncountable set CANNOT be partitioned into countably-infinite Equivalence classes where each Equivalence class consists of finite number of elements.
let f(x) be the probability that probability of heads is x;
We claim that there is a non-zero real number (say E) such that that set A = { y : y belongs to S AND f(y) >= E } is infinite;
If the above claim is true then the sum of all elements in F has to be at least sum of all elements in A which itself is at least E*infinity = infinity !!
To show that the above claim is true,
We consider sets Bi = { y : y belongs to S AND 1/i >= f(y) > 1/(i+1) }
We note that IF Bi is infinite then for E = 1/(i+1) the set A would be infinite and the sum would be infinite;
Now if Bi is finite for all i belonging to natural numbers,
We note Bi 's partition S,
and since Bi are countably infinite we violate our assumption and hence Bi cannot be finite for all i and this completes the proof!!!

It has a very good treatment of the core concepts, and an excellent selection of additional topics like Martingales and the Radon-Nikodym theorem. So far this has not changed my controversial take on this. I view the sum of zeros being equal to one as a proof by contradiction. I.e that the basic assumption that you can choose a uniform random real is false. Clearly the math works for any nonzero range. I even accept that taking the limit gives interesting and useful results. But, just as the singularity at the center of a black hole is a meaningless result from an otherwise perfect theory, picking a random real is an impossible action.
To summarize/generalize my view, taking limits to zero width is an extremely useful fiction. I.e. the resultant equations are valid, but asking what the area is at a single point is a meaningless question.
Hopefully this short summation of my ideas is clear enough for people to understand. If not, please feel free to ask for clarification.

What I use to understand this idea is that if you think about the probability of hitting any point is 0, but some zeros are greater than others. This way, all of those values are something times the same 0 (what we call in the know as dx), and this constant changes for every value. If you add them up, this set of constants add up to infinity, but they are arranged in such a way that if you multiply this infinity by that other 0 you get precisely 1. This way, if you just add a subset of it, you get something between 0 and 1, which is the probability. I remember playing with the Maxwell-Boltzmann speed distribution, and for temperatures really near 0K the small velocities reached values much greater than 1. However, if you multiply these probabilities by their respective 0 we call dx, we still get 0. If you add these infinite 0s up, you get a number smaller than one, so there isn't any paradox actually.

Here's a proof that the sum of uncountably many positive real numbers must diverge to infinity:
Given such a set of reals A, consider the subsets A_n defined to be the elements of A greater than 1/n for every positive integer n. Clearly, A is the union of all the A_n, since every element of A is a positive real and therefore greater than some such 1/n (in fact, infinitely many, but that doesn't matter). However, there are only countably many such A_n, and A is (by assumption) uncountable; consequently, at least one of the A_n must be uncountable, and thus in particular infinite. This implies that A includes infinitely many elements greater than some (positive, nonzero) 1/n; clearly, the sum must diverge to infinity.
I recall one of my professors giving us this proof, mentioning that it was a question often asked of PhD candidates; I thought of it as a variation of the pigeonhole principle.

Probability of 0 does mean it will never happen and therefore is impossible . In a more philosophical sense any kind of chance is 50-50, as it either happens or it doesn't. Regardless of whether it is possible or not. And regardless of the expected frequency for something to happen. Especially when it comes to an individual person and their experience through life, the only thing that really matters is whether something happens or not. It's not relevant if there's a 90% it shouldn't happen, yet you're 'lucky enough' to be part of the 10% of cases it does. Same goes for winning the lottery. Yes, so the chance is unimaginably small for someone to win (obviously), however I don't think anyone who ever won anything in a lottery will agree it made much of a difference. A chance of 0 does not mean it is possible, not even in mathematics. Because it suggests 100% of whatever is opposite of it would (always) happen. A small chance is different from no chance at all, ergo a probability of 0 is surely impossible. The only exception I can think of is when preconditions aren't met for something else to become probable, however it would be more mathematically accurate to take the full picture into account at that point anyway, instead of pretending there's no cause and effect at play and things would just spontaneously occur. In fact, I dare say a lot of probabilities would chance in an instant if conditions are more favorable towards one outcome than the other, as that's simply how reality works. If you never buy or own a lottery ticket, it will be impossible to win the lottery. If you buy just one ticket every ten years, you'll still have a much smaller chance to win than whomever buys a lottery ticket every week. To pretend someone who never buys or otherwise owns a lottery ticket magically has the possibility to win anyway, ergo an actual 0% probability is not an impossibility in and of itself, is crazy! In reality, a lot more things within reality are impossible than you'd think, whilst still an unimaginably large amount of things are possible at the same time.
